tossups.question: A long novel in this language discusses the narrator's father in 371 "numbered sentences," which are often multiple sentences. Another novel in this language contains 17 loosely-related chapters about figures like Nasrid Sultan Yusuf I, artist Pietro Perugino, and the carpenters rebuilding the Ise ("ee-say") shrine. This language's classic novel Confessions of a Bourgeois inspired a noble scion's later family chronicle (*) Celestial Harmonies. In 2015, NYRB Classics republished Len Rix's translation of a novel in this language about a writer's relationship with the male dog Viola and the housekeeper Emerence. Ottilie Mulzet has translated novels in this language like Seiobo There Below by the author of War & War and The Melancholy of Resistance; that author’s 1985 debut was adapted into a seven-hour film by Turin Horse director Béla Tarr. For 10 points, name this language of The Door by Magda Szabó and Sátántangó ("SHAH-tahn-tahn-go") by László Krasznahorkai.
tossups.answer: Hungarian [or magyar nyelv] (Péter Esterházy wrote Celestial Harmonies. Sándor Márai wrote Confessions of a Bourgeois.)

tossups.question: An albino woman imprisoned near this city reconstructs her past in The Book of Memory. The closeted Dumi rents a room from Vimbai, this city's top hairdresser, in a 2010 novel by Tendai Huchu. An immigrant nickname for London as "[this city] North" titles a 2009 novel by Brian Chikwava. Termite mounds inspired this city's passively cooled Eastgate Centre. A sadza-cooking single mom beats this city's top chefs in the ultra-low-budget rom-com Cook Off. An opposition party led from this city's Harvest House was targeted by 2005 (*) slum clearances in Operation Murambatsvina. Police hobbled this city's July 2020 anti-corruption protests by arresting members of Nelson Chamisa's MDC Alliance along with the author of This Mournable Body and Nervous Conditions, Tsitsi Dangarembga ("t’SIT-see dan-gar-EMB-gah"). For 10 points, name this city where a 2017 coup by ZANU-PF's Emmerson Mnangagwa ousted Robert Mugabe.
tossups.answer: Harare [accept The Hairdresser of Harare; accept Harare North] (The Book of Memory was written by Petina Gappah.)

tossups.question: "Essential writings" on this title subject were collected in a 2001 "reader" by photographer Moyra Davey. In a book titled for this subject, the narrator asks questions such as, "Am I just cursed by a demon?" which are answered by a series of coin flips. Rivka Galchen asserted that Louis C.K. was the best contemporary writer about this subject in an essay collection noting that it is characterized by both constant interruption and loneliness. A 2018 novel titled for this subject by (*) Sheila Heti includes a chapter titled "Bleeding." A Harper's essay on this subject by Alexandra Kleeman wrote about the "hoax" of bed rest, noting that it increases blood clot risks and does not prevent gestational diabetes. For 10 points, name this subject of numerous memoirs that describe the authors' struggles with postpartum depression.
tossups.answer: motherhood [accept being a parent or having kids; accept pregnancy or giving birth or equivalents; do not accept or prompt on "fatherhood"; accept Mothers: An essay on love and cruelty; accept Mother Reader: Essential Writings on Motherhood] (Galchen's book is Little Labors.)

tossups.question: The decline of this region is examined in a nearly ten-hour-long film subtitled West of the Tracks. Falling steel demand has hampered an economic revitalization program for this region, cutting into profits at Běimǎn Special Steel. The massive Dàqìng ("dah-ching") oil field is in this region, which was historically populated via the Guāndōng migration north through the Shānhǎi ("shahn-high") Pass. Máo-era economic success in this region drove up labor costs, making this "Iron Rice Bowl" into "China's Rust Belt." This region is considered the northern part of the Bóhǎi Economic Rim. Major cities in this region include (*) Liáodōng ("l’yao-dong") and Harbin. For 10 points, name this region of China consisting of Jílín, Liáoníng, and Hēilóngjiāng ("hay-long-jyong") provinces, which no longer contains many members of an eponymous ethnic group that ruled China during the Qīng dynasty.
tossups.answer: Manchuria [or Inner Manchuria or Northeast China or Dōngběi; accept Hēilóngjiāng or Liáoníng or Jílín or Guāndōng before any of them are read; prompt on Tiěxī District by asking "what province or general region is it in?"; accept Northeast after "China"; do not accept or prompt on "Guǎngdōng"]

tossups.question: This director cited Buffalo Bill's use of night vision goggles in The Silence of the Lambs as an example of how mainstream Hollywood films could be cutting edge in his college thesis on director Jonathan Demme. A shot in this director's most recent feature film references Stanley Kubrick's never-made Aryan Papers, a film he hopes to complete himself. tossups.question: A 200-dollar low-cost alternative to this brand-name technology was patented by the Frenchman Gregoire Gentil. An early demo of this technology that aired on Channel 4 in 2001 did not properly account for deformation. An ad deal with Ralph Lauren was apparently the reason why an improved "Live" version of this technology wasn't used in all instances at a 2020 event. tossups.question: Jennifer Kaufmann-Buhler's 2020 book on this title style traces its history to a design movement of the Schnelle brothers in the 1950s. tossups.question: One musical style in this country grew from the 2000 album Body & Soul: The Beginning and is a variation of American R&B with a long kick-drum beat. tossups.question: A Bloomberg Businessweek investigation of these things revealed troubling "ghost peaks" and detailed the loopholes used by a Chinese manufacturer of them called Huáhǎi. tossups.question: This novel, which extensively quotes from a text on aerodynamics, opens with the protagonist's father enrolling in a seminary school only to attend synagogue, take up billiards, and end up as a motel developer. tossups.question: Low-income residents of this metro area formed the Bus Riders Union to challenge discriminatory transit policies. Michael Manville, a professor at the Luskin School of Public Affairs in this city, found that most supporters of its 120-billion-dollar Measure M transit project don't plan to personally use it. tossups.question: This country's estate "The Plan" almost became a New Age center for the mother of a British author whose father quizzed him daily on the Encyclopædia Britannica. Wani and Nick Guest stay at the Feddens' holiday house in this country in The Line of Beauty. The second section of Julian Barnes's Metroland is set in 1968 in this country, where Chris views paintings like Jupiter and Semele at the Moreau Museum. tossups.question: So many escort services in this country signed up for CloudFlare in 2011 that this country now lends its name to a type of DDOS attack. The slogan "one state, one nation, one jacket" has been used to mock the blue plaid jackets donned by politicians in this country in imitation of its president. This country's currency rallied after its president fired his son-in-law and finance minister in November 2020; its economy was hurt by sanctions imposed from buying an S-400 air defense system from (*) Russia. Some protests in this country's most populous city were set off by a plan to build a shopping mall in the middle of Gezi Park. tossups.question: A Guardian critic noted how a cast of one of these objects by Rachel Whiteread titled Shallow Breath “is trying its best to inhale and exhale in the midnight hour.” A cucumber and two oranges are placed on one of these objects in the work that lends its title to the New Museum's 2018 retrospective Au Naturel devoted to artist Sarah Lucas. Performance artists Cài Yuán ("tsai y’wen") and Xī Jiàn Jūn ("shee j’yen j’ween") were escorted out of a gallery by security guards after attempting to (*) "improve" an artwork titled for one of these objects that was nominated for a Turner Prize. Connell's multiple forms of this concept include the "complicit" and "hegemonic," which C. J. Pascoe's ethnography about River High linked to using homophobic slurs. tossups.question: A graduate of "Neddy's" prosecutes a high-society murder trial in this country in the novel The Hamilton Case. bonuses.leadin: The NPS's Technical Preservation Services site highlights case studies of these places at the National Bohemian Brewery and Chicago City Hall. For 10 points each:
answers: green roofs [or living roofs; prompt on rooftops]
urban heat island effect [or UHIs; prompt on generic answers about heating or elevated temperatures]

parts: Name these energy-saving places pioneered in Germany, which may require HVAC upgrades before installation. Renzo Piano designed one of these places with dudleyas for the California Academy of Sciences.

Green roofs can mitigate this effect, which costs millions by raising air conditioning demand. It results from obstacles to wind flow, lack of vegetation, and the bulk properties of asphalt and concrete.
Another option for dissipating urban heat islands is installing surfaces like "cool roofs" with this property to enhance radiative cooling. It's the opposite of solar absorbance.

parts: Name this regular New York Times philosophy forum whose columns are collected in Modern Ethics in 77 Arguments and Modern Philosophy in 133 Arguments.

This philosopher identified the "paradox of tragedy," whereby we gain pleasure from watching a well-written tragedy. Galen Strawson's The Secret Connexion argues that this empiricist did believe in causal ("CAUSE-al") inference despite rejecting a regularity theory as merely "constant conjunction."

This "First Lady of Gospel Music" collaborated with Bishop Hezekiah Walker and Anthony Hamilton on her 2016 album Fill This House.

Water access was considered integral to "ensuring environmental sustainability," one of these eight aspirational statements for 2015 decided at a 2000 UN meeting. Other examples included reducing child mortality and eradicating extreme poverty and hunger.

The Millennium Development Goals singled out the special needs of "Small Island Developing States." The SIDS endorsed a 1994 "programme of action" named for this country, which is the headquarters of Future Centre Trust, aka Counterpart Caribbean.

murder [or homicide; accept justifiable homicide]

parts: Identify this country, the second-biggest market for music in the world. Tower Records, which still thrives in this country, opened an all-vinyl outlet in 2019.

Japanese law provided a carve-out for distributing CDs and cassettes in this fashion. Blockbuster, once the leading company distributing home videos in this fashion, popularized the electronic gift card.

This Japanese girl group pioneered the strategy of bundling tickets with CD sales to get people to purchase multiple copies of expensive albums. Their name derives from a neighborhood in Tokyo and they apparently have over 100 members.

bonuses.leadin: Ryszard Kapuściński ("RISH-art kah-poo-CHEEN-skee") reported on the effects of civil war in this city in Another Day of Life, translated by William Brand in 2001. For 10 points each:
answers: Luanda, Angola

Flanders [accept Flemish; or Vlaanderen; or Flandre; or Flandern; accept Flemish Brabant; accept West Flanders or East Flanders; accept The Lion of Flanders or De Leeuw van Vlaanderen; prompt on Kingdom of Belgium or Koninkrijk België or Royaume de Belgique or Königreich Belgien or The Sorrow of Belgium or Het verdriet van België] (The authors are Stefan Hertmans, Hendrik Conscience, and Hugo Claus.)
Easter Rising [or Easter Rebellion; or Éirí Amach na Cásca; prompt on the Rising]
parts: Name this city whose independence struggle inspired José Eduardo Agualusa's novel A General Theory of Oblivion. It has become one of the world's most expensive cities thanks to oil millionaires like Isabel dos Santos.

A slave trader from this region prospers in Luanda in Pepetela's 1997 novel A Gloriosa Família. This region, the setting of the 2013 novel War and Turpentine, titles a 19th-century novel about a "lion" that was adapted to film by an author who wrote a war novel about its country’s "sorrow."
In Sebastian Barry's novel A Long, Long Way, Willie Dunne fights in Flanders before facing this 1916 rebellion, which also inspired Jamie O'Neill's At Swim, Two Boys.

bonuses.leadin: A 2004 article by Joy Wiltenburg argued that this genre's "sensationalism" has roots in 16th-century Christian views of sin. For 10 points each:
answers: true crime [prompt on partial answer; prompt on non-fiction; accept "True Crime: The Origins of Modern Sensationalism"]
Monster
Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father
parts: Name this increasingly popular genre parodied by American Vandal. It includes the podcast S-Town and the docudramas The Thin Blue Line and The People v. O.J. Simpson.

Nick Broomfield reframed Aileen Wuornos’s true crime story in The Selling of a Serial Killer and Life and Death of a Serial Killer, but her public image was shaped by Charlize Theron’s performance in this 2003 film.

In this 2008 true crime documentary, Kurt Kuenne explored Shirley Turner's murder of his friend Andrew Bagby and murder-suicide of their son. This film inspired a bill from Canadian MP Scott Andrews withholding bail from convicted criminals.

bonuses.leadin: A tycoon from this country purchased Fortune magazine for 150 million dollars in 2018. For 10 points each:
answers: Thailand [or Kingdom of Thailand; or Ratcha-anachak Thai; accept Siam]
Time
Steve Case [or Stephen McConnell Case]
parts: Identify this country home to the Charoen Pokphand ("cha-RUUN poke-uh-PAHN") Group. Its hit TV show Love Destiny has revived interest in a 17th-century monarch served by Greek chancellor Constantine Phaulkon.

Before its acquisitions by Meredith and Thailand’s Chatchaval Jiaravanon, Fortune was part of a company named for this magazine. In 2018, Marc Benioff bought a controlling stake in this magazine, a long-time rival to Newsweek.
After the disastrous AOL Time Warner merger, this AOL CEO became chairman of the combined company. This man and Jerry Levin are profiled in Nina Munk's book about the merger, Fools Rush In.

bonuses.leadin: A 1955 San Francisco law required one of these things for each newly constructed residential dwelling unit. For 10 points each:
answers: parking spaces [or parking lanes; prompt on parking]
Telegraph Hill
UCLA [or University of California, Los Angeles; prompt on University of California or UC system]
parts: Identify these things that can be rented via apps like Pavemint. Chicago outsourced collecting fees from vehicles occupying these things in 2009.

David Chiu introduced a 2010 ordinance to remove minimum parking requirements in this San Francisco neighborhood. A 2007 law prohibited feeding the feral parrots in this neighborhood, which was named for a structure that signaled when ships were coming into the Golden Gate.

Donald Shoup's book The High Cost of Free Parking concludes that 22,500 dollars were spent on each parking space at this university where he teaches. This college's medical school is named for mogul David Geffen.

bonuses.leadin: Stattin and Kerr argued that this practice failed to improve Swedish parents' knowledge of teen delinquency. For 10 points each:
answers: parental monitoring [or parental controls; or surveillance; or location tracking; or spying on kids; or equivalents; prompt on parental restrictions]
snowplow parenting [accept lawnmowers or bulldozers]
free-range [accept free-range parenting or free-range livestock]
parts: Identify this goal of apps like Life360 and MamaBear, which are less extreme than the technology depicted in the Black Mirror episode "Arkangel." T-Mobile's FamilyWhere accomplishes this goal by detecting phones.

Parents' use of tracking apps seems to reflect "helicopter parenting" rather than this newer idea popularized by the 2019 college bribery scandal. This concept analogizes overactive parents to an object eliminating a child's potential obstacles.

In contrast, “Let Grow” founder Lenore Skenazy has championed a type of parenting described by this term. In a different domain, the EU mandates that products labeled with this term come from environments with continual access to open-air runs.

bonuses.leadin: A book titled for these two adjectives builds on the author's earlier notion of how the "outsider-within" offers a unique scholarly perspective. For 10 points each:
answers: Black AND feminist [accept Black Feminist Thought: Knowledge, Consciousness, and the Politics of Empowerment]
Barbara Smith
Clarence Thomas
parts: Name these two adjectives that describe the "thought" outlined by Patricia Hill Collins in her 1990 book about "Knowledge, Consciousness, and the Politics of Empowerment."

This woman's 1983 anthology Home Girls collects pieces by Black feminist and lesbian activists and authors. This co-founder of the Combahee River Collective and Kitchen Table: Women of Color Press still works for the Poor People's Campaign.
Smith's 2014 memoir Ain't Gonna Let Nobody Turn Me Around begins with a discussion of Anita Hill's testimony during this Supreme Court Justice's confirmation hearings.

bonuses.leadin: Leonard Zeskind's history Blood and Politics traces modern white nationalism to the rivalry between this man and the author of The Turner Diaries, William Luther Pierce. For 10 points each:
answers: Willis Carto [or Willis Allison Carto]
Populist Party [accept the People's Party]
Posse Comitatus [accept Posse Comitatus Act]
parts: Name this founder of Liberty Lobby and its newspaper The Spotlight. He and David McCalden co-founded the Institute for Historical Review, a California Holocaust denial press.
In 1992, Carto backed Christian Identity supporter Bo Gritz under this political party, which shared its name with one that merged with the Democrats under William Jennings Bryan in 1896.

The Populist Party lost votes from its rivalry with this "sovereign citizens" group that popularized armed militias. This group is named for an 1878 act limiting military police power, whose Latin name means "power of the county."

bonuses.leadin: Patrick Forterre argued that this superphylum was related to halophiles, criticizing the Ettema Lab's papers tracing its phylogeny with TRAPP domain homologs. For 10 points each:
answers: Asgard archaea [or Asgardarchaeota; prompt on archaea; accept Lokiarchaeota or Thorarchaeota or Odinarchaeota or Heimdallarchaeota; prompt on the TACK superphylum]
vesicles [prompt on liposomes; accept vesicle trafficking]
black smokers [accept black carbon]
parts: Name this proposed superphylum with a mythological name, which allegedly shares a common ancestor with eukaryotes.

The Asgard archaea may contain homologs of eukaryotic Sec proteins, which traffic these structures between the Golgi and cell membrane. Südhof, Rothman, and Schekman won a 2013 Nobel Prize for studying these compartments enclosed by lipid bilayers.

The Asgard archaea are named for Loki's Castle, a hydrothermal vent "smoker" of this color. This color names a carbon-based form of fine particulate matter that causes extensive radiative forcing in Asia despite its fast turnover.
